messageBody:
> Actually, that was JUnit 4 code. I wonder why people keep bringing up
> TestNG all the time? :-)

It's your bloody innovation that polluted our pretty old flawed jUnit
3!!! ;-) (or was that nunit?)
Ok, innovation is good, embrace change :)

> Definitely. In those cases, it's definitely fine to revert to the old
> try/catch pattern.

I think with exceptions annotations are not expressive enough. I don't
like that you can't be consistent and that annotations can encourage
not checking for that piece of information you were interested in
(that can make all the difference from a amintainance perspective).
RMocks way around that (in JUnit 3) looks like this (it was invented
because we wanted to support java 1.3 and then we found some more
advantages (subjectively speacing of course))


public void testForException() {
expectThatExceptionThrown(is.instanceOf(SomeException.class));
something.doSomethingThatShouldThrowException();
}

benefits:
* you can expect anything that can be found on the exception instance,
not only type or exact message (for messages; one or more anded
contains expressions are often better then asserting for the whole
message)

* The expectations gets moved into the code so you chancecs increase
that you /see/ it (doesent mean you /understand/ it any better than
annotations

* By placing the expectThatExceptionThrown just before the line that
you expect will throw an exceptioin you can avoid accidentally passing
the test because some setup threw the exception you were interested
in.

drawbacks:

* magical
* location: expectThat... must occur before the thing that throws an exception
* I'm sure others see some I don't, let me know
* same as annotations, framework tricks and not pure java can confuse newbies.
